data.text: Need a Good GPS Computer for Bicycle Touring and Bikepacking

Hi, I’m sure this question has been asked before, What would anyone suggest as a good all round GPS computer . Touring , road biking , mtb riding , Not to big , not too expensive, can load maps on , blue tooth to iPhone , polar HR compatible. Thank you Nick

This won’t be the most popular answer but it works for me. I use my phone and mount it to my bike via the quad lock case/mounting system. I use ride with gps and save routes offline so I can use them without draining battery as fast.

data.text: I’ve yet to find a good cycling GPS that has all-around good reviews. Even on the high end Garmin’s.. I’ve considered just going with a good cycling app and just using my phone. It’s just strange to me how you can’t enter your travel destination in to a biking gps and get turn-by-turn directions like you can with Google maps on your phone or something. It always comes out buggy.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: cycling GPS are extremely limited. You have to plan the route in advance, upload it to the GPS, and follow the line. The points of these units are - well insulated against rain - tiny cpu so they use very little power - battery lasts a long time. - you can pair sensors. I use HRM and powermeter, they are useful. But yes, otherwise they are junk compared to phones. And expensive.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: this is partly true...first yes you do get turn-by-turn directions and depending on the GPS you absolutely can pick a destination and it will route to it. Depending on the route and the type of cycling, Google Maps can be useless especially off-road where there are other third party apps that work directly with your bikes (or phone's) GPS to plot a route. That is their focus. Sure Komoot can plot a route on the road, but it an also plot a route on gravel routes and singletrack....something Google doesn't. Then on top of that it will send it to the GPS and provide turn-by-turn directions...something Google can't. If you want to use your phone and one of these 3rd party apps, by all mean... But bike computers have their purpose and they're very good and efficient at what they do.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Most unpopular opinion but Google has bike paths and trails on it too and availability for offline maps

data.text: Smartphone navigation is fine. I think OSMAnd works with iOS now and I highly recommend that app. You can create your own routes offline on the app with downloaded maps and follow gpx tracks downloaded from other sites. If you really want an actual bike computer, Wahoo Bolt or Roam work well for turn by turn navigation on a gpx route with good battery efficiency and cycling metrics. Unfortunately, they aren't cheap

data.text: I used @ridewithgps, and it worked great on my iPhone in airplane mode. My phone easily lasts all day in airplane mode, and one less device to carry.

data.text: I use an Etrex 32x along with my Garmin Fenix. The Etrex has the advantage of long life on easily replaceable/carriable batteries. The big disadvantage is the for that product is the antiquated USB transfer speeds. Additionally Garmin tools are not what I consider state of the art. That said I have had the Etrex family for many years. I have been using basecamp for many years. It is the ecosystem I am invested in. It is not just about the unit. It is also the ecosystem they provide. Routable maps, downloads and planning features. Battery life and power budget if in the back country. So what we use all comes with a cost. The head unit is just the start.
